subject: linear_algebra
title: Finding Eigenvectors: Null Space and Geometric Multiplicity
contentHtml:
Eigenvectors are crucial in linear algebra, as they help us understand how matrices transform vectors.

To find an eigenvector of a square matrix A corresponding to an eigenvalue λ, we need to solve the equation (A - λI)v = 0, where I is the identity matrix. This equation represents the null space of (A - λI), which contains all possible eigenvectors.
name: Eigenvector Equation" },
intuition: Think of the null space as a set of vectors that remain unchanged when transformed by A, except for scaling. Eigenvectors are special cases where the transformation is just a scalar multiplication.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, eigenvectors help in dimensionality reduction and feature extraction.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse eigenvectors with null vectors; they're not the same thing.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Finding Eigenvectors
contentHtml:
Finding eigenvectors is a crucial step in understanding the behavior of linear transformations. In essence, we're searching for non-zero vectors that, when transformed by the matrix A, get scaled by some factor λ.

Geometrically, this means finding directions in which the transformation stretches or shrinks the original vector.
name: Eigenvector Equation
intuition: Think of eigenvectors as special directions in which the transformation acts. By finding these directions, we can better understand how the transformation changes the original vector.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, eigenvectors are used to reduce dimensionality and identify patterns in data

subject: linear_algebra
title: Finding Eigenvectors: Null Space of (A - λI)
contentHtml:
Eigenvectors are vectors that, when transformed by a linear transformation A, scale up or down but do not change direction.

To find an eigenvector, we need to find the non-zero vector v such that (A - λI)v = 0. This is equivalent to finding the null space of (A - λI).
name: Eigenvector Equation" },
intuition: Think of eigenvectors as the directions in which a linear transformation stretches or shrinks. The null space of (A - λI) tells us where these directions are.
realWorldApplications: Principal component analysis (PCA) in machine learning uses eigenvectors to find the most important features
commonMistakes: Failing to recognize that eigenvectors can be scaled by any non-zero constant
